Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the danger of the new coronavirus vaccines by stating that they are more dangerous than getting COVID-19.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or support to back up its assertion that the vaccines contain toxic ingredients.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that receiving the COVID-19 vaccine is more harmful than contracting the disease itself, which is a problematic assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim fails to acknowledge the alternative explanation that the vaccines have been extensively tested and proven to be safe and effective in tens of thousands of people.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the vaccines have been studied for months and have been proven to be safe and effective, while COVID-19 has caused significant mortality worldwide.
Understate: The claim understates the potential benefits of the vaccines by suggesting that anyone who has had COVID-19 would not benefit from vaccination, which is not true.
Falters at times: The claim falters by making misleading claims about the new mRNA vaccines, such as the ability to alter human DNA, which is not supported by evidence.
